reviews.content: If you've been eagerly awaiting a revisit to the ragtag band of galaxy savers in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3, prepare for a bumpy ride through a nebula of disjointed narratives and characters that may just send you spiraling into an existential crisis.The film endeavors to spread its narrative galaxy-wide, focusing on each of our beloved guardians simultaneously. Unfortunately, it feels a bit like trying to watch multiple TV screens at once - great if you enjoy a galactic case of whiplash, but far less so if you prefer your movies to have a clear protagonist.The creators took a bold step into the narrative unknown, choosing to spotlight every Guardian's story simultaneously, much like Avatar 2. Sadly, the result is a filmic dish whose individual ingredients are delectable, yet when combined, induce a sense of cosmic indigestion. Rocket's story orbits at the center, yet it feels like an anecdote in a tale that's meant to be about everyone and no one in particular. Immersion takes a back seat as we, the audience, are left floating in a zero-gravity void of emotional disconnect.On the emotional side, this galactic opus comes across like an organ grinder cranking the handle of sentimentality, using every trick in the book to elicit feeling but leaving the audience as cold as Pluto.The Guardians' third outing resembles nothing less than a cinematic Frankenstein's monster. It stumbles between tones, veering from near-horror to slapstick childishness with the grace of a one-legged Celestial. It's akin to an ill-conceived roller-coaster ride that can't decide whether to scare you or make you laugh.Moreover, our galactic heroines, Nebula, Gamora, and Mantis (though Mantis less so), seem to be embroiled in their own version of "The Red Bull Chronicles." Their overly caffeinated, confrontational behaviors paint them as one-dimensional space rednecks, sidelining their previously established character depth. It's a sad sight as they devolve into irksome caricatures of themselves.Perhaps the biggest blow comes from the stark departure from the first two films. Our familiar guardians have been replaced by alien (and not in a good way) versions of themselves, creating a disconnection that has all the subtlety of a supernova.Despite its stumbles, the film does manage to mine some gold from the asteroid field. Drax delivers his usual razor-sharp humor, Mantis shows a glimmer of depth, and the cameo adds an unexpected twist to the cosmic soup.In summary, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 might appeal to those with a taste for narrative chaos and character disarray. However, for this viewer, it was a leap too far into the galactic unknown, leaving behind the charm and balance of its predecessors. The score? One star for Drax and one for the cameo, but overall, this is one sequel that fails to launch.
reviews.heading: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3: An Astral Misadventure

reviews.content: The third installment of the Guardians of the Galaxy franchise does not disappoint. Director James Gunn once again delivers a hilarious and action-packed adventure that will leave fans laughing and on the edge of their seats. The chemistry among the main cast is as strong as ever, with each character given their own moment to shine.The film's humor is one of its strongest aspects. The jokes are clever, and the delivery is spot-on. It's impossible not to laugh when watching the Guardians bicker and banter with each other. The film also doesn't shy away from emotional moments, which are handled with care and depth.In terms of action, the film delivers some truly impressive set pieces. The special effects are top-notch, and the fight scenes are choreographed to perfection. The soundtrack is also a standout, with a mix of classic rock and pop hits that perfectly complement the film's tone and style.Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a worthy addition to the franchise. It's a fun and entertaining ride that will leave audiences satisfied. Whether you're a fan of the previous films or new to the series, this movie is sure to be a hit.
reviews.heading: A Hilarious and Action-packed Adventure

reviews.content: What a disappointing film. In two moments I was about to get up from the theater and leave. It had been a long time since I had seen such a pretentious film. It was a mistake to emphasize the relationships between the characters because the vast majority of them have irrational expectations and behavior; It was another mistake to put Rocket's drama as a catalyst for the film because the villain depends precisely on his relationship with Rocket and that makes any sense of danger disappear. The villain is unfortunately the weakest in Marvel history and he really looks like a jester. If you expect entertainment you will find a couple of moments to laugh (thanks to Mantis) and some interesting visuals. The rest can be said to be pretentious, unbearable, tedious and generally leaves a very bitter taste in the mouth. I rarely yelled at the good guys in a movie theater, Die!! Yesterday it happened This is not the way to make a worthy or valuable film. To put it simply: it's rubbish.
reviews.heading: Really bad film, perhaps the worst of Marvel.

reviews.content:
This movie was really good. That's it,very sad and dramatic but funny with reason at the same time.Good to the point jokes and Rocket's backstory was really touching.After all this bad movies from marvel from the last years that I didn't enjoy at all, The Guardians proved their worth to the maximum. It was the only movie that I was counting on and thank God it was good.I was really waiting someone to die at the end but it didn't happend That's a little bit let down I have to say because I believe it will leave a good impact to the whole story
For me this movie is 09/10 for everything.Visually and with a good story.
reviews.heading: Finally

reviews.content: Marvel cinematic universe has produced more than 30 movies and new projects may not please your eye anymore. In spite of being a part of this universe, "Guardians of the Galaxy" have always stood apart from the rest of superhero movies. It's because of the heartwarming atmosphere, amazing soundtrack, humor, ironic attitude of the characters and exciting space battles.It is all the more surprising that the final part of the trilogy, directed by James Gann, turned out to be darker and more dramatic than expected. The film raised essential questions about the place of individuals in a huge evil world, the absurdity of the idea of an ideal society, and the importance of the life of every species as well. Even though the creators used obviously manipulated techniques to play on the emotions of the viewer, I would say that storyline of Rocket the Raccoon is the main advantage of the film and it really touches you. And I can't help saying that story wouldn't be so emotional and terrifying without an amazing voice acting cast.However, the main theme of the third volume is definitely friendship. Star Lord is no longer the main character and Gann has focused on developing all the team characters.The main cast, Dave Batista (Drax), Mantis (Pom Klementieff), and Karen Gillan (Nebula), got more screen time, they performed brilliantly and look very harmonious. Above all, Chukwudi Iwuji was fantastic as the villain. The High Evolutionary, creating a new world inhabited by a perfect race, makes you hate him. Although he is absolutely disgusting because of his actions, he is still attractive at the same time. I could add him to the collection of the most unpleasant villains from the comics.'Guardians' cause empathy and they sincerely please you with their appearance on the screen. The visual effects team did an amazing job bringing to life the fantastical universe. And what's more, the view of bio-structural planet was breathtaking and I felt like a child looking at the pictures in an anatomy book for the first time. The film ends very poetically with the song that opened the first film.In my opinion, this is a very worthy conclusion to the story, the best film of the trilogy, and one of the best films of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.heading: 89P13

reviews.content: I agree wholeheartedly with those reviewers who cite Vol 3 as the weakest of the GotG trilogy, which is a shame, because it could have been great.There was much to enjoy here, but equally there were elements that left me frustrated over what were, in my view, some poor choices of tone and direction.The main problems I had with this outing were two-fold: too much shouting (like being subjected to an episode of a cheap soap opera); and some horrendously mawkish sentimentality, which frankly made me want to vomit.I found the principal villain to lack depth of character. I don't believe it was the fault of the actor, having seen him in other things, rather the character's motivations were largely ignored by the script and direction. There is a moment between Rocket and the Evolutionary which could have acted as a trigger of a personality change, for example, but the Evolutionary seemed just as depraved and heartless before as after. Actually, this is a common complaint I have with villains in general - if they're unremittingly cruel and horrible to everyone, why does anyone follow them?Having laid out what I didn't like, there were some things which worked. I personally had no expectations of newer characters like the Space Dog or Adam Warlock (these are things which seem to preoccupy comic fanboys on the whole), but they were entertaining additions to the canon. The Guardian who amused me most consistently was Drax (he certainly did a lot less angry shouting than the others), and Groot was reliably entertaining. You might be forgiven for thinking that I am a person who lacks emotional depth, whereas in fact I found a lot to applaud in the way Rocket's back story was handled, but for me it got unnecessarily over-sentimental at times, and it would have been much more effective if that particular instinct had been reigned in.On a final note, I think the 2.5h run time was in danger of outstaying its welcome, which I would never say of a film I thoroughly enjoyed. A slightly trimmer and more tightly scripted and story-boarded film would probably have served the franchise better.
reviews.heading: MCU equivalent of a bag of Revels

reviews.content: Okay, here we have the newest installment to the Marvel franchise and the official title is "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3". I guess I will just talk a bit about the basics here and then move on in brainstorming fashion to some of the aspect of the plot of this movie. With the Avengers films over, of course we are getting closer to the end of the entire franchise, but a few more films are surely going to happen. This one here could be the one that is going to end the Guardians of the Galaxy sub-franchise then and it felt a bit strange to finally have a movie from the Avengers universe that does not have Dr. Strange in it. He has been everywhere literally before that. But yeah, this one runs for almost exactly 2.5 hours and this is the expected running time for a film like this I would say and overall I would also not have kept it much shorter. The scenes made sense. The one who wrote all those and is also once again the director is of course James Gunn. He has been part of the GotG films since the very beginning in both positions, so no surprise he is back here as well. I mean there was even a short holiday special last year I think and Gunn was on board there too, so no way he would miss out here. I am still curious about what he is going to work on when/if the GotG films really have their closure. Now? As for the cast, you will be getting all the familiar faces and voices again from the previous movies. I will not mention all the names now, but the one leading the gang is of course once more Chris Pratt's character and Pom Klementieff is also growing on me more and more. Interesting actress and with her I am also curious what she is going to work on next. Really nice to get a relatively unknown actress for such a key role, even if she had not been in it from the start. I also loved her little Fantasy Football endeavor song in-between.But yeah the guys are all really big names and the one of them with the most awards attention in the past is probably Bradley Cooper with all his Oscar nominations. Him we do not see here, but he is the one giving his voice to the racoon that does not want to be a racoon or actually he finally accepted his identity at the end of the movie here. Maybe not as much of an emotional and kickass movie as they wanted it to be, but it was alright. I love racoons anyway, so I am a bit biased here. This movie is a lot about this racoon character now, which made me especially curious to watch it as I knew beforehand, even if said racoon is mostly unconscious for the vast majority of the film and his buddies are trying everything they can to cure him and thus have to take a deep dive into the little creature's past. He is also called squirrel on one occasion, but not by one of the good guys. Anyway, the raccoon('s) story is so much at the center of it all that Pratt hardly felt like a lead character anymore. But that is okay. I am not a big fan of him either and always found him on the overexposed side. I mean good for him he managed such a big career coming from the (comedy) small screen initially, but yeah, not a fan here. Also not too much of Cooper by the way. Pratt/Quill then still gets a few big moments like when he is not ready to let the coon depart or when he almost dies towards the end then, but is saved by a new face of the franchise. It was alright. I still wondered how Quill recovered so quickly from this. Said new face is played by Will Poulter (always great recognition value, even if you cannot come up with the name immediately) who seemed like the main antagonist early on with his pretty quick showing in this movie as he attacks our heroes, but turns out he is just an aide of the real villain. And as you may have guessed at some point when he started treating this pet (in a way he is one himself) in a nice and caring fashion, he gets his second chance from the Guardians (I always keep writing Avengers almost, but oh well they are part of those too I assume) and even becomes one of them in the end and finds real friends. What happened with this female character there by the way who also belonged to the bad guys, was his instructor or mother or whatever?It is once again the bad guys where the film gets in new faces that have not been part of the franchise before. The lead antagonist is played by Chukwudi Iwuji. Big role for him and just like the main antagonist for the probably next Thor movie, this actor also proved himself worthy of a major big-screen role through his turns on the small screen. There is not much more to say to him. A touch of God complex and we have seen that in Thanos of course already. Overall, he is not the most memorable antagonist. What stays maybe most in the mind about him is the scene in which he loses his mask and we see what the young Rocket did to him back in the day. Bloody mess. The scene in which he blows up his revolting squad stayed memorable too. Honestly, for a little while here and there I felt as if I was watching Samuel L. Jackson. Where has he gone by the way? Anyway, what really makes you think at the end then that the GotG films may be over is the fact that two key characters decide to leave. Or actually three if you count Zoe Saldana's character among them already too. I mean she is not the Gamora she once was, but yeah in the end she returns to her bunch of criminals that also include Sylvester Stallone's character, even if he is seen only briefly. Quill and Mantis are the other two leaving and I find it almost sadder in terms of the latter, but who knows they might be back. Mantis' leaving also means at least a temporary delay to her potential love story with Dave Bautista's Drax. Pity. I like both characters. With Bautista I am also curious how he will keep going after this franchise. I mean if you look at all the stuff (Avengers, Bond, Blade Runner) he has been in by now, you can even say he has made it bigger than The Rock. At least if we look at the now. Should be interesting to see how this turns out. In any case, there is still a lot of work to be done and we see it a bit in the closing credits when Rocket Raccoon, the new leader, takes care of some alien creatures there. Two post-credit sequences may be one too many, however.What else? I liked how some characters had their special moments here where they once more could show us their talents. With Mantis it was how she makes some villains useless early on, but especially the scene in which she tames these creepy creatures that in the end even join her on her journey. How about a film about her future maybe at some point? I would love such a spin-off. And with Bautista's Drax, he is the one who makes sure all the children are safe when the two females are just arguing. That was also kinda nice and used to show us that he is not a likable fool or idiot, but much more than that. I indeed felt until that point that he was just brought in for some funny lines before that like the talking about who Quill's best and second-best friend is and way more than that, which was still so much funnier than Quill's allegedly funny lines when he asks if something was cool or also the usually failed humor from Tony Stark in this universe. So yeah, Drax may actually be my favorite funny character from the Avengers universe thinking of it. Nice delivery there from Bautista and good writing of course too. His moments make the film (or these films in fact) a lot lighter and will bring a smile to your lips here and there. Just some more brainstorming now: What is up with Sarah Alami in here and her character or the character's name? It was not even a S. Alami joke, was it? Man I would love to be named like this. I realize some former Moroccan tennis player came pretty close. Never thought of that. Oscar nominee Maria Bakalova is also in this film and I am not so sure if I really like her character too much, but it is a cute dog, so she can get away with it. But the "bad dog" joke they went with for a little too long maybe. The scene when she and her owner take care of some of the bad guys with their telepathic abilities was still cool. Said owner was played by Sean Gunn if I see it correctly, so this was indeed a bit of a family affair as he is of course the brother of the man who is the driving force behind this project. I think during the film itself the late Stan Lee was also credited as a writer or at least credited some way, but on imdb Gunn is the only writing credit. Oh well, nobody will forget about Lee anyway.There's surely more scenes and inclusion I can talk about here, like how I am still a bit surprised that Nebula is played by a White actress, that Nebula was also really close with Rocket looking at how she reacted when she found out he is alive or in general the scene when he almost dies. That was touching how there he sees his friends from his childhood, the other deformed animals and it was nice to see they were doing fine and also that they did not kill him off. I definitely want a Guardians movie with Rocket leading the gang. Or at least another 40-minute special. Make it happen! Other than that, it was once again maybe not too realistic how all the heroes survived this movie despite occasionally hopeless situations and the antagonist, if we look at his powers when he is presented to us as some kind of god almost, was also defeated a bit too easily for my liking. Quite the team effort though. That is almost all then as the character limit is close. That gigantic pig creature from the bad guys was interesting, but sadly dead too quickly. I also felt sorry for the spy or what it was and how he is bullied on one occasion and killed not much later. Nathan Fillion played the bully there. That actor also has great recognition value always. That is really it now, the newest Guardians of the Galaxy movies is a good watch, but not a great one. You get exactly what you came for here. Plus some drop-dead gorgeous baby raccoons already in the first shot. See it.
reviews.heading: Another spectacular entry to the series, story is alright as usual

reviews.content: It feels a bit like the sending off of James Gunn and not of the GOTG. I loved the story of rocket, but this took away everything which made the first couple of movies great. Lots of jokes, light hearted and this has less of that. The jokes in this movie are dragged out and feel forced.The high evalutionary is not a great villain, it's just a big man child. I don't think you can blaim the actor though. The same issue is there with Adam Warlock. It is a child and nothing more, there are a few nice moments but for me it felt like these two characters where just in it because the movie needed a villain, but at no point you feel the urgency or any form of threat level.At last, the ending was real anti climactic. It felt a bit like end game in the sence it looked like they said goodbye after 20 movies. For me this was a bit drawn out.I liked the movie, and will watch it again, but for me not the best part of GOTG by any strech. Just an ok flick.
reviews.heading: No villain, long ending, to little humor...

reviews.content: Usually trilogies go first one being the best second one is the runner and third is just ok.Not in this case guardians of galaxy 3 is as good as first one if not a little better just a little different story line.Especially Rocket story it does touch your soul they made the scenes really deep.Dave Bautista ( Drax) he played excellent, especially as a dad !Peter as always good very charismatic funny and excellent play.Nebula was excellent you can understand how much she needed a family and how much she was fit for a familyGamers to be honest I had feelings sometimes that she was somebody extra in the movie that doesn't need to be in.Overall 8.7 out of 10.
reviews.heading: Rocket!

reviews.content: In review, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a concluding trilogy that is quite fun and satisfying to watch.The laughter in the studio will be one of the things to remember when watching GOTG 3 on the big screen.The visualization delivered by cinematographer Henry Braham is also quite good, remembering when Quill did the escape from the High Evolutionary plane.Then, no less important in editing, GOTG 3 is still classy as it depicts the magnificent headquarters of the Orgocorp company.The acting of the cast is solid, plus new characters like High E, and a Warlock who are stronger enough. Chukwudi Iwuji played his role dramatically, very well and was able to hold the audience's attention when he appeared on the screen.Will Poulter as Adam Warlock is also very suitable, as is known in the actual story he is ridiculous and stupid because he is still very young, and you could even say he's still a baby.His goofy appearance may confuse audiences a bit, but that is the true character of Adam Walrock.He was just born from the metamorphic process and was born in a golden form, tall, handsome, and full of cosmic power because during his cocoon he absorbed cosmic energy.Overall, GOTG 3 succeeds in presenting action, humor, and emotionally stirring sentiments, as well as providing an unforgettable experience for the audience.
reviews.heading: Gotg 3 is solid

reviews.content:
& its just a cash grab move.Although all the action scenes are superb & I am tired of appreciating MCU 's extravagant cgi , All i am going to focus is Peter Quill. Starlord really abandoned that annoying child side & it feels good to have a normal matured empathetic protagonist for real. Everything else? Everything else is actually downright average. Yes. It actually is.Before criticism
Should I remind everyone that mcu never actually portrays death as a significant stop of life? Them suddenly realising *oooh oooh those children who grew up watching superheroes in literally everything never have seen an emotional scene , how about we kill a character & emphasize on it heavily??From Sam Raimi's Spiderman to Avengers Endgame, many characters have died. Some of them were killed of in a mocking manner like maximum charcters from Thor 1 to casualties happened during Avengers 1 & Age of Ultron. Then again some scenes still haunt my dreams like Spiderman 's uncle Ben dying in Raimi's Spiderman.So what is the big issue here?An arrogant pirate of a raccoon who never behaves properly lost someone dearly. Which us , humans generally deal with our entire lives. Is that supposed to make this movie best MCU movie ?Except that
What is even there to appreciate?LMAOyou call that an Adam Warlock? I ll find you guy who ll break this Will poulter into two pieces within a second.The bad guy looks like a shordy version of Kang.Story is basically nullSpace looks absolutely boring with badly made Aliens? Animals? I saw a spider with his face glued , was it a spider in cage when Rocket attacked the Antagonist? Or just a cheap looking thing derived from a child aged 6's drawing book? I ll never know.Director might have thought everyone must be crying so nobody's gonna notice at anything else .&That director
Whats his name ? Yeah James gunn.& Everyone who is rating this movie based on the emotional turbulence needs to see good old classics
Shawshank redemption
The green miile
Hachi : a dog's story.Requirem for a dream
EtceteraSo that
A superhero movie or any superhero universe which has been average & full of cringe comedy doesn't get overrated score just because it deals with pain , suffering & loss of a loved one .James gunn will definitely be back with his cringe humour and billions of dollars
&
Yes once in a while he might kill a character.For him
That is like the comedy is at 95% after that.But,
I hope this movie makes some kind of change in the heart of those spoilt brats who is going to be the next bully among his colleagues. Especially those who have rated this movie a 10 or 9.Wouldn't it be funny if they just go back to what they were before?Yea.James gunn type of characters. Life changing movie . How's the cash flow though? Pretty good again isn't it?Hollywood at its best.
reviews.heading: One thing I know: Animal cruelty is bad , another thing i know: Marvel doesn't actually care for any animals

reviews.content:
I know that I have a minority opinion here so go ahead and rip me for it.ANALYTICAL BREAKDOWN
There are too many instances of characters shouting over each other in this film. The characters do not appear to have any intelligent conversions. At all. Like seeing people argue in a homeless camp or a subway. I can't believe this. It comes off very depressing.The first two movies were fun. The first was the best and the second was only slightly less great. But this one? It's tone is all over the place. One minute its goofy and the next we are seeing animal cruelty. Drax is easily the most entertaining character. By far. The other ones were just acting like children all of the time they weren't fighting.The music was the worst of all three films. Predictable. Boring. The villain was also one-dimensional. Rocket's story is just too depressing for this type of film series that used to be about having fun. This is really bad.
reviews.heading: Not as good as the first two. Bizarre and depressing.

reviews.content: In a time that we tend to hide feelings and things like empathy, we are given this.Honestly I had seen some shorts dedicated to Rocket and I knew I had to see it. There was no disappointment!Each character shined - it was a movie about family and what lengths you would go to to save a family member.The music hit. From the beginning.The character strengths and flaws.A villain that we know all too well in reality. And what many of us wish we could do to that villain.I will give you one caution - you will cry. You will feel. You will love and understand CGI characters like never before. Honestly certain moments haunt me. Like I said four days later and I still hear Floor in my head.Overall a fantastic ride with heartfelt emotion, a bundle of laughs, and a great sendoff too our favorite group of A-Holes.
reviews.heading: Four days later....

reviews.content: An absolute emotional rollercoaster. Arguably the best trilogy ever made?...The storytelling was first class. The ability to create laughter, tears and a gripping story cannot be underestimated. I'm a huge fan of the first two movies and was a little nervous of the often fatal, 'third film' but I'm relieved to say it was beyond anything I imagined.This was Marvel back to their best: excellent character development, stunning visuals and a decent story to boot.So if you're a fan of the first two, then you must see this film. And if you haven't seen the first two, go and see them first.Bravo to everyone involved.
reviews.heading: Flawless.

reviews.content: It has some fine elements but generally lacks the warmth and character of the previous two with all the usual James Gunn missteps.Arguments that just seem a little too intense to be funny.Inconsistencies like, one second Quill has problems driving a car, saying it's a long time since he was on Earth. Minutes later, Drax takes off on a motorcycle, presumably having never seen one in his life, and drives away without issue ...Quill is escaping an exploding building and for some reason there's a cutaway to Drax telling him he's running out of time... for why? Isn't that obvious? Way to break up the action and kill the pace ... Gunn seriously needs an editor.Quite who the antagonist is and why he behaves the way he does is never really explained, he just follows one McGuffin after another, to keep things going.As the movie progresses we are presented with a stream of his creations which just seem to be there to up the ante. No explanation, no real depth or establishing who/what they are...So, good but full of things that make you go hmmm. 6/10.
reviews.heading: All the usual James Gunn misteps

reviews.content: This is an excellent movie. Really love it. I love the whole franchise myself; started watching all of the MCU films since 2017, and absolutely love it! No wonder it is a mega-franchise; people really do love it! The soundtrack for the movie was also the best. James Gunn really did a great job in the making of this film.Except for one thing, in which, honestly, I don't think he (James Gunn) should be fired for this, but at least get a reprimand for what he did in the Counter-Earth scene with the car. You see, that scene featured the MCU's (in movies) first F-Bomb ("Open the F#%*!$& door!"), and to be honest, I thought it was kinda funny when I saw it in the theater. But, however, this really kinda pisses me off a little bit, being that the MCU films stayed (kinda) family-friendly, but this blooper really screwed things up. The MCU will get Deadpool 3 in 2024 (and I hope they'll at least put out a PG-13 Disney+ exclusive version of the R-rated film, maybe with Walker Scobell becoming Kidpool), and I really hope, to be on the safe side of things, it gets distributed under the 20th Century Studios banner (not Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures), just as not to confuse the consumer.Other than the F-Bomb Ad-Lib, the movie was great! Will buy Awesome Mix Vol. 3 (already have Awesome Mix 1 and 2) and put all three on a flash drive to listen in the car.
reviews.heading: Love the movie, the franchise, everything. Excellent soundtrack. Just one little detail that needs to be addressed, though...

reviews.content: I am a huge Guardians fan and have seen 1 and 2 over and over.Guardians 3 is, for me, too dark, too sad and too long. I would consider it completely inappropriate for children (unlike its predecessors). It lacks the vibe and energy of 1 and 2, instead wrapping itself in disturbing images.The movie works too hard, and doesn't deliver many - if any - laughs. If anything, it made me realize the importance of Rocket's constant commentary as a mechanism to maintain story momentum.This is a movie I won't watch again. I do hope the Guardians have some kind of a future, and I hope they bring back the fun.
reviews.heading: I hoped for better

reviews.content: G3 checks out all the boxes to make an entertaining movie. Bunch of things and characters get jammed in, but in the most predictable Marvel way. There are a few interesting things like an organically grown facility and all the shenanigans that take place there. But ultimately, it's more of the "theme park ride" that Marvel fans expect. Movie becomes a bit draggy in runtime. The best parts are often undercut with needless comedy in typical Marvel fashion. The cgi-environments designs are quite interesting and perhaps the best part of the movie to watch on the big screen. There is a glorious fight scene which some people might love. There are a few non-sensical things that are I guess very typical in Marvel these days. Is it a bore fest? No. But it's more of the lowest common denominator of Marvel movies.
reviews.heading: About 45 minutes too long. Fun?

reviews.content: There is a lot of action, and there is a lot of killing. There is a lot of casual cursing-the kind of cursing that someone who curses a lot curses like. There are quite a lot of scenes that caused me, as an adult, emotional distress. I cried a lot during this movie. This is a very good movie that I would not bring a kid to see. I would probably bring a kid to see Fast X before this movie. That said, I saw this in IMAX and it's the best makeup, costumes, DP work, CGI work etc that I've seen in a movie so far. The action scenes are very very good because of the DP work. For the bad... There was just too much music used. I can't even remember what songs were in this movie, and I saw the movie last night. However, I can remember the songs in the first GOTG. Some of the story just didn't make sense or seemed unnecessary to me. Like the ending. Subjectively, I just don't like the ending. It doesn't make sense considering the plot of the movie. There seemed to be a lot of stream of thought adlibbing or dialogue that just seemed like ADHD bouncy braining of a script writer, which I didn't care for since I personally deal with it in daily life. I don't like what they did with Groot's dialogue. Overall, Rocket stole the show as usual. Love him. I'm glad I saw this in theater-specifically IMAX. It was definitely made for it.
reviews.heading: Not for kids

reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulPeter Quill/Starlord (Chris Pratt) roams the universe with his galaxy defending companions, still reeling from the death of his beloved Gamora at the hands of her father. However, he and the gang are thrust back in to action when Rocket (Bradley Cooper), the feisty raccoon, is mortally wounded, and they desperately need to find a cure. They are put on a collision course with The High Evolutionary (Chukwudi Iwuji), an intergalactic being who wants to wipe out humanity and start a new world. Along the way, shocking revelations thrust him into a battle with destiny.Well, my golly gosh, out of nowhere, a third (and apparently final) GOTG movie has crept up on us. I had no awareness of it's pre-production or any sort of publicity surrounding its release, other than a poster outside a cinema. With a six year gap between the release of the last one, and nearly ten years since the release of the original, the series seemingly got sucked up in the MCU orbit, with the Avengers series of films, and the relevance of a third film seems somewhat deflated. And the film itself feels like a reduced copy of what's gone before.The formula from the first two films is there, and writer/director James Gunn's style and approach is evident at various points throughout, with some funny moments and quite a funky soundtrack. Yet somehow, it also all feels like a more heavy and solemn affair, without the carefree spark and joy of the first two. The story feels a little piecemeal, and at an indulgent two and a half hours, it can feel like a bit of a strain. The usual gang, including Pratt, Cooper and Dave Bautista as Drax, have developed their own chemistry over time which rolls on here, however, Iwuji is overly hammy and theatrical as the villain (in spite of Starlord's humorous observation of his resemblance to Robocop), whilst Will Pointer's role seems kind of pointless.This is what average Guardians looks like, I guess. Three's always a charm, and maybe there was an inevitability about its arrival, and while it has some charm and fun, it's inferiority to the first two is pretty clear to see. ***
reviews.heading: Surprising third entry into the Guardians trilogy, showing the end in sight

reviews.content: Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed some of it, but it was a really weak first half plot wise. If you missed the holiday special, or forgot who golden boy was, you couldn't be blamed for being quite confused.The second half of the film was much stronger, some good humorous dialogue between the main cast, some newer characters were fun, and decent action sequences raised the score, but generally it felt like a bit of a jumbled mess, and there were so many eye rolling moments that actually made me groan out loud.I WOULD like to see different Guardian line ups, maybe as an ongoing tv series, and did enjoy the mid credits scene!My least favourite Guardians film, and I didn't really like ego from volume two!
reviews.heading: Weakest of the three Gaurdians films

reviews.content: OK first off, what happened to Nebula's breasts? Look at them, they are smaller much smaller. SHE is women right? (Sister) and the standard anatomic feature of women is breasts, but hers are almost gone..... They were noticeable breasts in Guarding of the Galaxy I .. bring them back please. Stop transforming her into a thing. She is a woman.Some anal Cruelty, but animals as pets is cruel too. I wonder how much money they pay Vin Diesel just for putting his name on the cast. Groot has no lines??? Dave Bautista saves the show most of the time, just being Dave and Chris Pratt puts it all into perspective as the only human on the team. His pay, no matter how high is still too low. A great actor who comes across as down to earth and like the friend you could depend on when it hits the fan. reviews.heading: Guardians of the Galaxy III; The amazing disappearing breasts of Nebula

reviews.content: I must say, Guardians of the Galaxy, Volume 3 left me utterly unimpressed. This so-called "galactic adventure" falls flat on its face, drowning in a sea of darkness, disturbing imagery, and excessive violence. From start to finish, it's a cacophony of despair that fails to engage the audience in any meaningful way.The incessant yelling throughout the film quickly becomes grating and annoying. Seriously, does every character have to shout every line? It's as if the director mistook loudness for passion and forgot about subtlety altogether. As a result, any potential character development is drowned out by the noise, leaving us with a group of teammates who achieve nothing but headache-inducing chaos.The final ten minutes, while sentimental, come across as ridiculously contrived. It's as if the filmmakers tried to inject a cheap emotional punch to salvage the wreckage they had created. Sorry, but a few touching moments cannot redeem the previous two hours of darkness and despair.In essence, Guardians of the Galaxy, Volume 3 is a misguided attempt at storytelling. Its relentless bleakness, disturbing content, and excessive violence overshadow any potential enjoyment. The obnoxious yelling only exacerbates the frustration, and the sentimental finale feels forced and out of place. This film, quite simply, fails to live up to its predecessors and leaves the audience longing for something more substantial.
reviews.heading: Guardians of the Galaxy, Volume 3: A Disappointing Symphony of Darkness

reviews.content: I am really surprised at how many great reviews there are out here for the movie. I mean it wasn't a bad movie but it was not anywhere near the 1st two. It seems like they tried to mimic the DC comics which generally is more dark. This movie did not even come close to feeling like the first two which in of itself isn't a bad thing, but it was like couldn't decide what kind of movie they wanted so they split it down the middle. I guess I need to go back but another thing was all the swearing. I don't remember any swearing in the 1st 2 but it was predominate in 3. Also on of the more subtle things with the franchise was the sound track. They seemed to move away from that and why he had the recordings at all. I think like a lot of these kind of movies they rely on the CGI too much which this one did. The bad thing for me who was a big fan of the franchise I will not miss the fact that they will not be making #4 which is the rumor. Another thing, for me some of the characters are much better than others and they seemed like they wanted to evenly distribute the action between all of them which doesn't work for me either. They are called supporting roles for a reason. If they try to make spin off I will probably pass because I am sure none of them will be of the best characters.
reviews.heading: Not sure where to start here

reviews.content: This movie was really awesome, and I thoroughly enjoyed viewing this movie in the cinema with my friends. Usually, constant flashbacks and memories scattered throughout a film is rather annoying and it kind of pisses me off, but I feel that the movie was put together in a way that made these scenes feel less annoying and instead really entertaining. The antagonist was kind of dumb and I don't really know how I feel about him along with the rest of his gang, I also don't like how abrupt rocket's revival was. But those are very minor issues and are really just my main criticisms. I really enjoyed the movies and highly recommend seeing it especially if you liked the last couple!
reviews.heading: Best guardians of the galaxy Movie!

reviews.content: Totally flabbergasted this is a 12. There is so so so so much violence.I haven't seen many of the superhero movies the past couple of years so perhaps this is the trend now, but the level of violence in this movie shocked me - every few minutes there was violence. I'd be really horrified to think of a child watching this movie.On top of that it's pretty graphic / gruesome in a number of places, I'd definitely say to extremely unnecessary levels - like isn't this movie partially aimed at the younger generation?I get that you will always have a fight scene or two in these movies, but the level of violence felt totally unnecessary and didn't help serve the plot at all. Just shocks me to think this movie could pass as a 12, and would strongly advise anyone who can be sensitive to movies to really do their research before considering watching this one.
reviews.heading: Absolutely no way this is a 12

reviews.content: The whole movie is about the injury of the rocket, and thus understand the past of him. The higher evolution was the boss of rocket and the golden people in episode 2. It was an intellectual creature and thus wanna catch it. The relationship between the guardians are still good and warm, and there are funny scenes in between. The most touching is the evolve and the death of the friends of the rocket. The other characters are with less influence in this movie. The new golden man character is very funny and I fear starlord was dead at last. Anyway it seems they will get apart soon, is this the last episode?
reviews.heading: Rocket...

reviews.content: It's no secret the MCU is running on fumes with the exception of a movie or show here or there ever since Endgame (No Way Home, Multiverse, Loki, Wandavision.) On the other side of the coin, not only have there been some really bad content but there's just too much of it since Endgame and it's going to cost them. Empire comes to an end regardless but Disney is speeding up the process.Having said all that, Guardians was finally a movie going back to what made the MCU so good for a decade. This movie is fantastic in its own right because it's tough to beat the first or second. I'm going to miss Gunn because he really grasped how to run a franchise and he's proof of what works. This installment had its action and humor but it felt a little more darker with Rocket's backstory.I don't know what's next given the end credit teaser with Star Lord and Pratt in general along with the "revamped" Guardians but I really hope this is it with that group. Great job.
reviews.heading: MCU needed this one

reviews.content: Why even make this movie if key elements of what made the first two so good aren't even it? We all know, and they go out of their way to repeat over and over again, that this isn't the same Gamora. And the movie is just not as good without her and her relationship with all the crew in general, and especially the very compelling relationship with Peter. It's bad enough to remove the two biggest stars from their biggest relationship roles in driving the franchise. They also take Rocket away from the crew for the vast majority of this movie as well. And he was the primary driver of so much of the rest of the relationships, not to mention the action and the fun. Mantis and Drax can't carry the whole movie any more than Nebula and, well, Nebula, as her character also suffers from the loss of her relationship with her sister Gamora. The Rocket backstory was interesting but it's not take up nearly half the movie with four brand new all CGI characters that pretty much only interact with each other interesting. The first act is mildly amusing and fun. The second act drags on forever. The only really good part is the final act when they are finally all back together in a way that vaguely resembles the action, fun, and spirit of the first two movies. In a way in glad this isn't doing as well at the box office as the other two because if this is the best they can do with these characters we don't need any more.
reviews.heading: If that's the best they can do yeah pull the plug it's done

reviews.content: Excelent movie, it deliveres what it needs to deliver. Nobody expects a Marvel movie to be the best one ever on history, and even so, this movie manages to be great for what it is, with funny characters and comments, marbelous soundtrack (I mean, WHAT a soundtrack), touching scenes and character backround (very crude at times, it impressed me that I was crying all throughout the movie) and good animation. The best of the 3 so far, and the best one I've seen by this studio (though I must admit I haven't seen a lot).Couldn't agree more with the person that said, and I quote, "a scene between an intelligent raccoon, a rabit with artificial legs, a walrus with wheels and an otter with metal arms made me cry".
reviews.heading: Just what it needs to be

reviews.content: In the final part of the trilogy, the world - or at least "one" world - needs to be saved by the Guardians of the Galaxy while the group deals with its own internal issues. The premise without much complexity is common to hero movies, including good hero movies, as were volumes 1 and 2 of this series, and as is this Volume 3. The trilogy, since its inception, has highlighted the right mix between action and comedy, with a thin dose of drama to not make a fantasy involving a talking raccoon too silly. It was working very well. But the frustration with the hero movies of recent years - mainly the result of too many releases and little creativity in scripts underestimating the intelligence and patience of the public - ended up causing apprehension about Guardians 3. In the end, the action scenes seem more of the same - not many, to a remarkable extent. Negative points are also the initial 30min a little dragged and a poorly worked transformation that the "new" Gamora goes through. All this, however, becomes less important in the face of the best of the film, which comes from the unexpected: Rocket's touching origin, the foundation of the plot. Yes, it's the exciting scenes in the story of a raccoon that make Guardians 3 more than a good action movie: in addition to the already expected good comic footprint, there's a great drama, which gave a surprisingly positive density to this farewell... although the post-credits scenes may suggest what they suggest.
reviews.heading: More drama than action - and that's great

reviews.content: This movie seemed to be more serious than the other two; but it still has its clever moments; which is why guardians are my favorite from the MCU. The trailer had me filled with such anxiety that I was laser focused on the story line and perhaps missed some funny parts. But when they hit, they were perfectly timed. Toward the end of the movie, I realized I was feeling jostled around with ups and downs, visually and emotionally, similar to the ride at Disneyland. This is a great thing! It is solidly entertaining and visually stunning. The violence in it was triggering for me personally. If you are an animal lover or are triggered by aspca commercials, you'll find discomfort here. I'm a wimp but I do appreciate the message it was sending. It has people angry about the horrors treating animals poorly and that's important. At times the violence with all the characters was shocking; with more blood it would have been R, no question. But Gunn walked the line. I think it's too much for younger kids. It was very well done and I can't wait to see it again.
reviews.heading: Excellent and violent

reviews.content: A great finale, with good character developments and really good mixture of comedy and drama. GotG saga will always be my favourite one among the MCU and for this I love and hate this movie.I've loved especially the character of Nebula. How she became basically the most balanced character of the whole crew and did it so perfectly still amazes me.Here's what I sadly can't stand. What I'm about to say might seem a little naive, but I hate how they ended ALSO Quill and Gamora's love story.Starting with the fact that of all the couples in the MCU, theirs was my favorite, I point out that the ending of the movie, where Quill stops chasing the "new" Gamora, was maybe the only reasonable one. For her to fall in love with him again would have been ridiculous, to say the least. However, I kept hoping that their story would continue, because their saga, the Guardians of the Galaxy saga, has always been, for lack of a more specific term, the craziest. But most of all, what pissed me off was the fact that their story is just the latest in the list. So far, the only couple in the MCU that has actually ended well is Steve Rogers and Peggy Carter. In all the others, either one of them dies (TS&PP, WM&V, NR&BB, T&JF) or, as in the case of Peter and MJ, he decides to let her go. I don't know why exactly. Maybe not to play with the happily ever after, or maybe because movie sagas are now like drama TV series, where no couple can end fine unless the actors stay together until the end of the series. Zoe Saldana stated that while she hopes the producers can find an actress to take over the role of Gamora, she made it clear that this is her last movie in the MCU. Basically, I resent the fact that Quill and Gamora could not end their story on a positive note. It may be a little childish, but for me, that's one of the main reasons I didn't walk out of the theater thinking, "Wow, I've never seen a more perfect saga ending!". I admit I have no idea how James Gunn could have saved their story, but after more than 30 movies with basically the same scenario, the ending that cannot be positive about a relationship is now the real cliché ending, for me.So while I still regard this as the first good movie, along with Spiderman No Way Home, after Avengers Endgame, I still note that the drama put on it ruined a little a saga that shined also for his lighter tone, with lots of fun and not too much tragedy.
reviews.heading: A great finale, but with an ending I didn't appreciate much.

reviews.content: The MCU lately has definitely had its ups and downs. Since the release of Endgame there has been a lot talk about whether the MCU is good anymore. I myself believe that as a whole the franchise has take a downturn but I still think it's good. Certain projects I think are great such as NWH, Shang-Chi, Loki, werewolf by night, but I also think they're are quite a few duds such as she hulk, Thor love and thunder, Quantumania, Eternals. To me the biggest issue is them trying to force in too much which causes a lot of character issues as well as rushed plots and resolutions. Even the films that and shows that said were great were brought down a notch because of those issues. But here we have Guardians 3, made by James Gunn who is one the only filmmakers that Kevin Feige and the rest of the studio for the most part can't influence and that is why This film is above everything released since Endgame.This film is the perfect conclusion to the trilogy, it raps up storylines for each character all while delivering an emotional roller coaster packed with comedy, action, and all around great storytelling.The performances are some of the absolute best in the MCU including Chris Pratt who definitely stepped it up for this film. The Villain played by Chukwudi Iwuji is top notch and I would consider him to be the best in the trilogy.This to me is the best film in the trilogy and I hold Guardians 1 very highly. But this film elevates in every way and makes for one of the best films in the franchise.My only gripe is one that I am guessing may not have been James Gunns choice. Adam Warlock was bad, I mean really bad. He was used for nothing but comedy and most of it wasn't that good. He didn't have any real impact except for at the beginning and he didn't have an impact again until a certain spot towards the end but other then that he felt very much like a characters that did not need to be there.But overall this is an excellent film and I hope that one day we will at least see these characters return in another film.A.
reviews.heading: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 review

reviews.content: I am 100% aware there were no real animals in this film, but the torture and killings of the animals in the flashbacks were too much. If you're a big baby when i come to sad animals, maybe skip this one. Im not a big marvel person, but have seen the first two GotG. This seems like it would have made a better series plot than a movie. Also they seemed to tack on a bunch of big names to this one and it pulls you out of the movie to see them. And lastly, why did the one planet have to be orgainc? It was like a weird scene taken out of the magic school bus and seemed unnecessary. Overall disappointed.
reviews.heading: Harsh watch for the sensitive

reviews.content: I love all of these movies but this one's got the perfect plot and brings the origin of rocket which is one of the only marvel comics I read. If marvel continues the starlords story which it sounds like they will I would greatly appreciate it. I feel like Star Wars need to go more into this direction by giving us more sequels and less prequels. Maybe another villain trying to take over the galaxy or something. This movie typically has the best character development all but one character but I ain't gonna spoil it.like I said gurdians of the galaxy is MCUs best and I hope marvel keeps making some cool stuff.
reviews.heading: Best of the 3

reviews.content: I had high expectations for this one and it delivered. It was even better than I hoped for and easily the best out of the 3 GOTG movies.The story was great, I loved the backstory, the visuals were nice, the songs were perfect and the soundtrack was hauntingly beautiful, which added a lot to the already emotionally packed scenes.The villain was awesome, I loved the way the villain was introduced and the ideology was really interesting.10/10 would recommend watching it. Especially in the cinemas to get the full experience. It's totally worth it and I will definitely watch it again sometime.The fight scenes were epic and the serious scenes really hit you in the feels, so get those tissues ready.
reviews.heading: Great story, great villain, hauntingly beautiful music

reviews.content: 5 out of 5 stars.Guardians of the Galaxy vol. 3 is an awesome superhero film that is a perfect end to the trilogy with action, emotions, and a great direction arc that concludes to the characters we love.The plot is great. It involves a bit of a backstory to rocket raccoon. And how he came to be. And a story involving the High Evolutionary played by Chukwudi Iwuji who is the villain. The film is big, fast paced, and action packed. It is filled with a bit of a emotional story which can be dark and concluding characters arcs. James Gunn script and direction does know how to handle the pacing, action and emotional story.The visual effects are amazing. The music score and soundtrack is great. Great cast ensemble. Plus new additions like Will Poulter and Chukwudi Iwuji which they deliver. The action sequences are big and exciting.Overall, this third Guardians film delivers it all. And i can not wait to see where it goes next.
reviews.heading: Guardians 3 is just amazing and ends in a high note.

reviews.content: "Guardians of the Galaxy 3" is not only ideal ending for this series in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it is considered one of the best movie of Marvel in the last few years, and we are once again reminded of how far the Marvel Cinematic Universe was before these disappointing films. Be It has been fun and interesting. This series is one of the best in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and James Gunn gave them a very good digital ending.Guardians of the Galaxy 3 movie is Marvel's return to the factory, and for this film series, it is a heartbreaking and tear-jerking story that, despite a lot of chaos, has maintained itself on the characters.By watching the movie "Guardians of the Galaxy 3", we can conclude that James Gunn is a director who can balance the needs of companies and studios and blockbuster filmmaking.And in the end, This show is undoubtedly the best Marvel movie since Avengers: Endgame. It is an emotional journey that was totally worth waiting for..
reviews.heading: The best Marvel movie since Avengers: Endgame!

reviews.content: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3, directed by James Gunn, is an exhilarating and emotionally charged conclusion to the beloved space-faring franchise. With its infectious blend of humor, heart, and cosmic action, this film proves to be a worthy addition to the Guardians' legacy, delivering a satisfying farewell to our favorite ragtag team of misfits.The story picks up after the events of Vol. 2, diving deeper into the origins and personal journeys of our beloved Guardians. From the very beginning, the film strikes a delicate balance between lighthearted comedy and poignant character development. The witty banter and offbeat humor that defined the previous installments remain intact, keeping the audience thoroughly entertained throughout the entire runtime.Chris Pratt returns as the charismatic Star-Lord, leading the team with his irresistible charm and quick wit. Zoe Saldana as Gamora, Dave Bautista as Drax, Karen Gillan as Nebula, and Bradley Cooper as the voice of Rocket Raccoon all give standout performances, effortlessly capturing the essence of their characters and showcasing their growth since their first adventure.One of the film's biggest strengths lies in its exploration of familial bonds and the power of redemption. The complex dynamics between characters, particularly the relationship between Star-Lord and his father, Ego (played brilliantly by Kurt Russell), provide an emotional core that adds depth to the intergalactic spectacle.The visual effects are nothing short of breathtaking. From the vibrant and imaginative alien landscapes to the thrilling space battles, every frame is a testament to the creativity and technical prowess of the filmmaking team. The seamless integration of practical effects and CGI creates a truly immersive experience, making each action sequence a visual feast.James Gunn's direction is masterful, effortlessly blending the film's various elements into a cohesive and satisfying whole. The Guardians' trademark soundtrack, featuring a fantastic selection of '70s and '80s hits, perfectly complements the exhilarating action and injects an additional layer of nostalgia into the narrative.Without giving away any spoilers, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 delivers a conclusion that is both emotionally resonant and filled with surprises. It ties up loose ends while also leaving room for future possibilities, a testament to the care and attention given to the characters and their journeys.In conclusion, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a stellar and fitting finale to the beloved franchise. It strikes the perfect balance between heartwarming character moments, side-splitting humor, and dazzling intergalactic action. James Gunn's remarkable storytelling, combined with top-notch performances, stunning visuals, and an unforgettable soundtrack, make this film an absolute must-see for fans of the Marvel Cinematic Universe and beyond.
reviews.heading: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3

reviews.content:
MCU is back and this time with one of the best movie ever...
The lovely team of Guardians is back...
I am so happy that this trilogy is concluded in good way...
Everyone done amazing work...
The CGI is stunning...
The emotions are so real... I cried so much and I was not able to stop crying at one particular scene...
The Peter Gamora relationship, The Drax mantis relationship, The Cosmo kraglin fun, Groot last line, Nebula new powers and Rocket backstory everything is well done... I also enjoyed Will as Adam warlock... Rocket friends are so cute...
Overall a perfect goodbye to Guardians and I am going to miss them...
reviews.heading: MCU one of the best movie...

reviews.content: If there was literally any doubt in my mind as to whether the MCU had inadvertently ended after the events of "Avengers: Endgame", 2023's latest "Guardians of The Galaxy: Volume 3" dispelled the remaining hesitation I may have potentially harboured (in regards to that uncertainty), clearly performing as a beautiful (tonally, far more distinct) final chapter to the cinematic universe in a movie which acts as the narrative equivalent to party-goers sentimentally bidding adieu to each other in a warm, savoury embrace (tearful their time's drawn to an eventual close, yet fond & happy they even had it together in the first place, however fleeting) after one of the best nights of their life; the music perhaps might still be playing afterwards (if those in charge of the speaker system wish to prolong the experience) - but that's what the sound has transformed in to from this point on - not a home for those seeking memories, friendships & family (originally drawing them in like moths to a flame - they've all left) etc. Just noise. Therefore, I'd argue with a fair degree of confidence it's officially over now & those who remain, continue to linger for the sheer sake of it.I say this because James Gunn's evidently moved on, creatively; here, he carefully gives each & every character within the ensemble as much closure as it's humanly possible to provide within the confines of an increasingly corporate franchise & basically says everything that can theoretically be said. Sure, you could plausibly add to it (& unconvincingly tack on extras)... But why would you - when the stories' already rewardingly completed?As for V3 (in & of itself, not worrying about what it possibly represents within the grand scheme of the production companies' future plans for blockbuster comic book adaptations), I've gotta admit I was genuinely shocked (this is not one you should take your kids to see unless you intentionally want to traumatise them) at the impressiveness of the sci-fi's quality - possessing one vital ingredient I've often bemoaned other (Marvel) installments for lacking (heartfelt sincerity) & also, a refreshing, palpable maturity; as Peter, Gamora, Rocket, Drax, Nebula etc. Have grown in their own right, so has the creator of the trilogy developed too as a writer. Ergo, he delves in to truly DARK subject matter & consequently, his progression allows him to intimately explore more meaningful themes of identity & morality, challenging every member of the team personally (seriously, the stakes have never been so personal) until they reach the crux of their destined emotional journeys (satisfyingly paying off established arcs, a decade in the making) - & using the lessons learned to artistically reflect ourselves back at us (the viewers), purposefully reaffirming how humanity is ultimately flawed, doomed to chase an abstract concept which is never achievable; perfection - refuting that endeavour (despite the acknowledgement many shall never relinquish the fruitless pursuit) & authentically embracing its bizarre quirks (shining like much needed bright lights against the grim bleakness) in one of the best & most macabre dystopian works of fiction I've seen put to the screen in ages.
reviews.heading: Poignant.

reviews.content:
My Review- Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 (2023)
My Rating 7.5 /10I'll admit Cartoon Super heroes are really not my specialty and a little out of my comfort zone however I was entertained and enjoyed the escapades of Star Lord Peter Quill played by Chris Pratt as well as my favourite character Rocky Racoon sorry Rocket Racoon voice supplied by Bradley Cooper ,Drax the warrior played by Dave Bautista ,Nebula the adopted sister of Gamora played by Karen Gillan and my 2nd favourite character Groot a member of the Guardians who is a tree-like humanoid and the accomplice of Rocket .I mean it as a compliment that Groot Played by Vin Diesel gave a very wooden performance in a role that gave him plenty of opportunity to branch out .I enjoyed the light comedy touches in Galaxy 3 and the chemistry that the comrades in arms had together it gives the story a human touch .Although saying that the humans or humanoids are few and far between ,especially on Counter Earth a planet created by the villain of the movie titled The High Evolutionary a scientist played by Chukwudi Iwuji . This Classic mad scientist has populated Counter Earth with his created anthropomorphic animal creatures that mimic the everyday lives of our planet Earth which has destroyed itself with corruption and War.The movie opens on a planet or place called Nowhere which reminded me very much of the seedy Cantina bar scene in Star Wars where we're introduced to characters just as strange and just as seedy.The action begins with an attack from a warrior Adam Warlock who critically wounds Rocket which sets the action when the Guardians are unable to tend to Rockets wounds prompting Peter Quill to sets off find the combination of the kill switch embedded in the beloved raccoons head to save his life .It's a fun and exciting romp of a movie reminding me of the Saturday matinee movies I grew up watching .Whether it's Our Gang, The Three Musketeers, Harry Potter and his Gryffindors or The Magnificent Seven buddy movies have audience appeal so I suspect this is the case with The Guardians.Where todays Saturday matinee movies differ of course is due to the technology as they are certainly more spectacular of course .They are far more innovative as they would be with a Production budget that any treasurer would be envious of ."Guardians of the Galaxy 3" cost $250 million to produce and roughly $100 million to promote fortunately for Disney its a huge box office hit already with a $528.8 million in global sales in its second weekend in theatres.There's fortunes to be made for all in The Guardians of the Galaxy movie franchise including it's star Chris Pratt . His father in law Arnold Schwarzenegger put his full support behind his son in law and was very proud of the result.Chris Pratt's estimated net worth to date is $80 million not bad since his first Galaxy movie was filmed only nine years ago.I imagine Disney were pleased to welcome Director and screenwriter James Gunn back to the fold after his dismissal in 2018 his contribution is obviously crucial to the box office success of Guardians of the Galaxy.
reviews.heading: Spectacular Saturday Matinee buddy movie

reviews.content: What an amazing movie this was. Seann Gunn you did it once again. The stakes are higher than ever and guardians embark another dangerous journey.I was excited to go to watch Guardians sequel on the big screen after 6 years and it surpassed my expectations.It had very good jokes although not all of them were so good, great action scenes, acting was great, soundtrack, CGI is awesome.It has many surprises and it introduces great and interesting new characters.This movie deserves all the praises it gets. Im looking forward to see more of GOTG in some in the future maybe a tv show or in videogames.
reviews.heading: Amazing end to a wonderful trilogy

reviews.content: I loved the satire and comedy scenes of the movie, the timing and acting was just great, as was expected of a cast like this. The story was good too, and after watching the last couple disappointing ones from Marvel i was hoping for better. However, they didn't improve on some things.First of all, what was the point of Adam Warlock. I literally did not get his characters point in this movie. The omni-potent Adam Warlock who was literally a God in the comics, was passed out half the film because of an explosion, and by the end of the film, had forgotten his mother was killed by the antagonist.Secondly, Rocket's friends were very irrelevant for the story line. I would have felt a lot more emotional if they had been given a story, but nothing. They just called Rocket 'friend' so we should feel sorry for them. Have you seen 'The Boys'? You know why the audience feels for Billy and his wife? Because they gave the audience something to connect to.I got alot of other things to say but let's just keep this shorter than it should be. Anyways, I did enjoy the movie and i'm looking forward to future Marvel movies, just not expecting Kang Dynasty to have even nearly the same level as Endgame.
reviews.heading: I enjoyed it but it still disappointed

reviews.content: I still can't think about this movie without getting upset. And it's a Marvel movie -- I'm a huge Marvel fan. I never would have imagined I'd walk out of a Marvel title, especially GOTG, but I did after I couldn't take watching animals kept in cages in dark dungeons, surrounded by their own waste -- that's how the movie begins. It escalates from there. At one point during a traumatic scene, I just closed my eyes. Then I left. I feel sorry for parents who take their children -- Disney got its way ending up with a PG-13 rating. It should be rated R simply for being so disturbing, apart from the F-bomb and other adult moments. So disappointed. I'm hoping The Marvels and The Thunderbolts are at least fun -- I don't even care if they lack substance at this point. I just want to NOT feel like I felt watching this movie. I realize I'm sensitive to animal cruelty, but I'm honestly amazed at how many people had no problem watching this.
reviews.heading: Traumatic Experience - So Disappointed

reviews.content: Despite being burnt-out from superhero movies lately the wife and I decided to go since we got 1 free ticket. Went in expecting nothing more or less than your typical Marvel movie but left the theater feeling like I'd just seen one of the best Marvel movies since watching the first Iron Man on the big screen when everyone was hyped-up over the start of the MCU. GOTG 3 is definitely going to feel more like an origin story for Rocket and it's one of the best origin stories, it's full of laughs like Marvel has been known for but it's also going to get dark and it's probably one of the more violent MCU movies short of Deadpool. I'm not usually an emotional guy but this movie had me wearing my heart on my sleeve not only for Rocket but there are plenty of other emotional moments involving other characters that will tug at your emotions. Well done by the entire cast and crew, it's sad to know this is the last time we will see this group together whether James Gunn at the helm.Go see it, it's worth at least 1 viewing on the big screen.
reviews.heading: Emotional roller-coaster

reviews.content: As a fan of both Is marvel and the guardians of the galaxy Wow all I can say is well this was the entire triology And it's no secret why it's doing very well at the Box office. And I personally thought That this Film Very emotional and serious but also funny and It's what you'd expect from a guardian of the Galaxy Film And the interaction Of Adam warlock in this film was very good but and this film perfectly sets up another sequel with rocket As The leader and Adam warlock joins the team which I can't wait for and I also can't wait for whatevor movie or TV show. They do. With starlord recommend it.
reviews.heading: Good ending

reviews.content: What happened. Absolutely loved the first two Guardians films. They had the feeling that they were all a family with some great humour entwined. This was like watching a horror movie. I had my eyes shut through a lot of it. I don't like animal experiments at the best of times. I know it was Rockets story but did they have to make it so horrendous. It was mainly loud explosions and the characters shouting at each other. They kicked the whatever out of the mixed tape and music. What made it worse was our Odean cinema had the sound way too loud my ears were ringing afterwards. The other two movies had me laughing, crying and wanting more. This one I wanted to walk out of half way through. It seems to have become like a lot of the other Marvel movies. Just action and adrenaline and not much else.
reviews.heading: Didn't enjoy

reviews.content: Okay this has no doubt been on my wait-list for forever and lemme tell you that I am thoroughly pleased with the outcome of the movie it made me smile I laughed I felt a race of action and adventure and it was so nice seeing the crew again for one last time especially mantis it's a all around good time at the movies but this does take an emotional tole on you once you get a look at rockets passed it's kinda sad to see that this is all too real with animals and lemme tell ya it's definitely not for kids due to that and some profanity and intense violence but a wonderful film a absolute must see.
reviews.heading: A fabulous film but watch about sensitive kids

reviews.content: I went into this film with really low expectations since the last couple of movies films have been more than forgettable but this movie was something incredibly different, James Gunn was able to make a great ending for such an amazing set of characters by expanding on everything we thought we knew about them the main example would be rocket raccoon (which once again was played brilliantly by Bradley Cooper) and how the plot and the villain revolve mostly of his back story which was an incredible story to show how he became who he is all while making the audience tear up.Chukwudi Iwuji did an incredible job of selling the threat the high evolutionary was and frankly, I found it refreshing that Marvel is doing villains who are just pure evil where I feel like in the past couple of movies they have made they have tried to make you feel empathetic for the villain wherever it's the villain trying to reconnect with their family (Doctor Strange: Multiverse of Madness) or whether they are avenging their family (Thor: Love and Thunder) so it is nice to see a villain who you can see as just pure evil and completely deranged.Once again every member of the guardians were played so well by each actor with some old side characters such as nebula taking centre stage this time which I thought was really enjoyable and nice to see such a good character being put into the spotlight and the same with kraglin who in the past was just a background character behind yondu but now hes a full fledged character trying to prove to the team he can be useful like yondu was and the new character introduced being adam warlock (whos played by the comedic genius will poulter) was a fun and charming character my only problem with him and really the whole film is that hes called this top of the evolution chain superhuman but really throughout the film he does not do much hes just there and the only relevance he plays to the plot being at the start after that he just pops up every 20 or minutes (side note: I personally wasn't the happiest with how they used him overall as in the original comics hes this powerhouse who was used to take down thanos so to reduce him to just some little side character who doesn't show off too much power just feels like a injustice to a very important character in the marvel universe but is coming more from a comic fan then a movie critic).Any film following a team that's directed by james gunn whether they are a group of renegade heros trying to protect the cosmos, a team of criminals sent out to be toys for the government to earn their freedom or a team of young mystery solvers, he always knows how to capture that team and/or family feeling with the bond between them all whether it's the serious moments where lives are on the line or just sitting around having a banter james knows exactly what to have them say and do to make to make them feel like they are all a real family and the same works with how he makes the films this film was such a bright and fun bit of entertainment for all the family to enjoy which knows when its time to be dumb and silly and when to be serious and it all works so well with eachother where like more recent marvel movies you could have a serious and tense scene but then all that serious feeling be taken away by a badly timed joke which hasn't landed well but that's not what happens here all the jokes and funny moment stay to their own parts to not ruin the impact the seriousness some of the moments in the film had.
reviews.heading: A theatric and tear jerking conclusion to a great marvel series

reviews.content: I honestly dont get why i seem to be the only one who didnt think this movie was good especially being in a trilogy with 2 other great movies. It makes me wonder if others just like it because they have been so deprived of good marvel movies for these past 2 years or so. Yes, people are right when they say its one of the best marvel movies since endgame, but other than spiderman no way home, all other competition is bad cinema that isnt hard to beat.First of all, I didn't like that the medpacks were just now introduced. I dont remember ever seeing them before and I think they put them in just to have plot armor for every main character except rocket, just to what, enhance the already high stakes? We dont need to be spoon-fed the fact that rocket is in danger, we couldve completely understood that without it. Its pretty obvious that it is just a useless plot tool so the the writers can be lazy and have characters get into fights with no consequence on their health to be able to do another one right after. If youre going to write a story where you dont have time to include any injuries or deaths, then just dont let them get hurt in the first place??Secondly, since the main villain had these incredible powers capable of stopping all his guards who were pointing guns at him ready to shoot.
